title.narrative: Denmark’s contribution to HURIDOCS project on co-creating the future of digital investigations with human rights defenders

description.narrative: HURIDOCS (Human Rights Information and Documentation Services) is an NGO that helps human rights groups gather, organise and use information to create positive change in the world. Founded in 1982, HURIDOCS has developed methodologies and software tools that make it easier not only to manage collections of evidence, law and research, but also to analyze them for insights. This project aims at a growing need for human rights defenders (HRDs) that engage in efforts to advance accountability and justice: a state-of-the-art software tool that helps them record, manage and analyse human rights violations in a way that is easily adaptable to local contexts, while protecting sensitive data on sources and victims. The need for such a tool is timely, as existing alternatives have reached their end of life, just as threats against the digital resilience of HRDs are increasing, and the amount of potential information that HRDs can leverage is growing exponentially. HURIDOCS will be to cooperate with partners on the ground in Cameroon, China, Egypt, The Gambia, Iraq, Mali, Mexico, Myanmar, North Korea, Palestine, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Turkey and Ukraine.

comment.narrative:
The baseline is highly dependant on context - in some of the locations, formal national and international (transitional) justice efforts are already under way, in others, not. Nonetheless, common understanding exists that documentation, memorialisation and preservation efforts are key for a future possibility of justice, healing and growth.
Target (2022): - At least 10 Organisations using the software tool report that it significantly aids their efforts in furthering at least one of the impact indicators.
